description: Dashboard showing ZFS pool and dataset statistics

panels.title: Pool Health Status
panels.description: Current health state of ZFS pools. ONLINE = healthy, DEGRADED = redundancy compromised, FAULTED = pool is inaccessible.
ZFS pool I/O errors. Any non-zero value indicates potential hardware issues or data corruption. Read/Write errors suggest disk problems, Checksum errors indicate data integrity issues.
panels.title: Pool Errors
Pool Capacity
panels.description: Percentage of pool space used. ZFS performance degrades significantly above 80% capacity. Keep below 80% for optimal performance.

panels.title: Dataset Read/Write Rate
panels.description: Data throughput per dataset in bytes/second. Use the Dataset filter to focus on specific datasets.

panels.title: ARC Cache Hit Rate
panels.description: Percentage of read requests served from ARC cache. Higher is better. Values above 90% indicate effective caching.

panels.title: ARC Cache Size
panels.description: Current size of the Adaptive Replacement Cache (ARC) in memory. ZFS dynamically adjusts this based on system memory pressure.

panels.title: ARC Hit Rate Breakdown
panels.description: Cache hit rates by request type. Data = file content, Metadata = directory/inode info, Prefetch = predictive reads. Low prefetch rates are normal.

panels.title: ARC Memory Distribution
panels.description: MRU = Most Recently Used (new data), MFU = Most Frequently Used (hot data), Anonymous = data being actively modified.

panels.title: ARC Size: Target vs Actual
panels.description: ARC dynamically adjusts between min and max limits. Target is the current goal size. If actual frequently hits min, consider increasing ARC limits.

panels.title: Compression Ratio by Dataset
panels.description: Calculated as logical_used / used bytes. May differ from ZFS's compressratio due to metadata overhead. Encrypted datasets may show inverted ratios due to encryption overhead.

panels.title: Pool Fragmentation
panels.description: Pool fragmentation percentage. High fragmentation (>50%) can impact performance, especially for sequential workloads. Consider pool replacement if consistently high.

title: ZFS Overview (test)
